author: @smithiness
text: ‘keyring’ is another library that can be used if you don’t want those values in text files.

author: @tobenary
text: Thanks for sharing. I'm using the find_dotenv() as well to avoid errors  from dotenv import load_dotenv, find_dotenv load_dotenv(find_dotenv())

author: @tacozmacleo
text: There is also the build-in Library called netrc.

author: @TheFarFey
text: While this archieves a seperation of code and secrets, it is no more secure than a simple plaintext file. Any secrets should always be stored encryped at rest.

author: @LongBeachRunner
text: This is fine for wireframe work, or poc work. However in production you’d want to call something like aws param store for your secrets.

author: @1986pinak

author: @Nxck2440
text: why not just use a regular text or json file? why use a whole dedicated library?

author: @tomwozne
text: Why not just create a class/variables .py file with your sensitive information then import it to your code base, then simply add that file to .gitignore
